sub_title: Founding partner and owner Casanova+Hernandez architects
summary:
‘Casanova + Hernandez Architects’ was established in Rotterdam in 2001 in order to experiment and build the new urban habitat of the XXI century.
  
The office activities are focused on the three linked fields that make a sustainable urban development possible: urban planning, landscape architecture and architecture.
This global understanding of the design is explored in every project from the large scale associated to the territory and the city till the smaller one related to the design of the architectural space and the technical details.

Some of the research topics developed at our office related to urbanism, housing and working functions are: sustainability, flexible urban planning, mix of functions, living and working, hybrid buildings, new ways of living, flexible buildings and urban regeneration of the post-war neighbourhoods.

Complementary to this research the office looks for contemporary solutions for public buildings like exhibition spaces, cultural, educational and sport facilities.

These research topics are theoretically developed via academic activities at different universities, debates, lectures, exhibitions and publications and are tested in the practice via international competitions and realized buildings.

Tirana, Albania', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}, 'end': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}}, 'description': None, 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Helena', 'last_name': 'Casanova Garcia', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Founding partner and owner Casanova+Hernandez architects'}]}, {'title': 'Albanian Carpet', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2020}}, 'description': 'Nominated for the Mies van der Rohe Prize 2021

Shiroka is a fishing village located on the shores of Shkodra Lake, near the border with Montenegro. Its inhabitants lived for centuries from the lake, men fishing with small rowboats and women tending orchards and weaving carpets by hand. The reaction to the end of a communist regime that had deprived citizens of living from traditional “private” activities was widespread mistrust in the public sphere, which led to a period characterized by uncontrolled occupation and privatization of public space. As result, the public space of the waterfront of Shkodra lake was occupied with illegal constructions such as private houses, restaurants, private parking areas, and kiosks. “Albanian Carpet” returns the waterfront to the citizens demolishing the illegal constructions, opening the views over the lake, and creating an alive public space with a domestic character.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Helena', 'last_name': 'Casanova Garcia', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Founding partner and owner Casanova+Hernandez architects'}]}, {'title': 'Black and White Twins.
